moves.1. b3: A classic case of mistakes emboldening the enemy
moves.1... e5: I opened (as black) with not much attention on the game
moves.2. e3 d5 3. c4 d4: I made this move to capture territory, and keep the game in his backfield
moves.4. exd4 Qxd4: My queen was brought out into battle too early from my perspective in retrospect
moves.5. Nc3: but I conceived a checkmate early if I could hoodwink my opponent
moves.5... Nf6: until he threatened my Queen, I would work my Knight into the battle
moves.6... Bg4: I like my development at this stage - I have momentum, mass and territory
moves.7. Qxb7: This move  should have opened the door for me to execute my mate strategy...but I am an idiot!
moves.7... Qxf2+: so I did this because I was not paying attention and made my attack one move too early! Silly me.
moves.8... Bd6: and worked hard to get out of trouble, and bring the fight to my opponent
moves.9. Qxa8: sacrificing my Rook in the meantime
moves.9... O-O: so suddenly, I am behind on points and behind in development and looking certain to lose although I have a pretty good cadre of soldiers, and might be able to pull off an upset.
moves.10. Nd5: so I have work to do as he develops his attack. I do feel secure behind my castle though, and hope to keep him at bay.
moves.10... Ne4+: depending on his answer to this move, I see a possible mate developing
moves.11. Ke1: I have to get my second Knight into the battle with both his escape routes covered
moves.11... g6: and create an escape route of my own just in case.
moves.12. Qxa7: This move gave me a great chance to feint an attack on this Queen while I maneuvered to my pending checkmate.
moves.13. Qa4: this retreat does not help him and in fact ensures that mate is a real threat
moves.13... Nd4: one move to mate...he only has one or two options to escape, but fails to see them
moves.14. d3: instead he threatens my knight which allows me to execute
